subject: history
title: Constitutional, Administrative & Judicial Development (1773-1853)
description: Major Acts that shaped British administration in India before 1857

events.title: The Regulating Act of 1773
events.description: First step towards parliamentary control over EIC

context.background: EIC's mismanagement and corruption in Bengal after Battle of Plassey (1757) and Diwani rights (1765) led British Parliament to intervene
context.trigger: Great Bengal Famine (1770), financial crisis of EIC, misrule reports

mainProvisions: Designation of Governor-General: Governor of Bengal made Governor-General (Warren Hastings was first)
Executive Council: 4-member Council created to assist Governor-General
Supreme Court: Established in Calcutta (1774) with Chief Justice and 3 judges
Control over Presidencies: Madras and Bombay subordinated to Bengal
Court of Directors: Tenure increased to 4 years; 1/4th to retire annually
Shareholders' Rights: Voting qualification increased to ¬£1,000 stock
Restrictions on Employees: EIC servants prohibited from private trade
Accountability: Company required to submit reports to Parliament
details.significance: First Parliamentary intervention; recognized Company's administrative functions; laid foundation for centralized administration
limitations: Supreme Court jurisdiction unclear, conflicted with native laws
No provision for coordination between Governor-General and Council

events.title: Pitt's India Act of 1784
events.description: Established dual government system (Board of Control + Court of Directors)

context.background: Defects of Regulating Act 1773; conflicts between Governor-General and Council; need for more parliamentary control
context.proposer: William Pitt the Younger (British Prime Minister)

mainProvisions: Board of Control: Created (6 members including 2 Cabinet ministers) to control political affairs
Dual Control: Company controlled commercial affairs; Board of Control supervised political affairs
Governor-General's Powers: Strengthened; could override Council in special cases
Presidencies: Governor-General given authority to control other presidencies
Secret Committee: 3-member committee of Directors to handle confidential matters
Declaration of War: Required permission from Crown
Territorial Expansion: Prohibited without approval
Civil Servants: System of civil service established
details.significance: Established dual government; brought political administration under British Crown while retaining commercial functions with Company; system lasted till 1858
details.keyPoint: This system of dual control continued until 1858 when Company rule ended

context.background: Lord Cornwallis appointed as Governor-General; demanded more powers
context.reason: Strengthen executive authority; reduce Council interference

mainProvisions: Governor-General's Authority: Given power to override Council in special cases
Commander-in-Chief: Governor-General could be Commander-in-Chief simultaneously
Emergency Powers: Special powers during emergencies
Council's Role: Reduced interference in executive decisions
Board of Control: Authority enhanced
details.significance: Strengthened executive; enabled efficient administration; Cornwallis implemented major judicial and administrative reforms

relatedReforms.title: Cornwallis Reforms (1786-1793)
reforms: Exclusion of Indians from higher posts

events.title: The Charter Act of 1793
events.description: Renewed Company's monopoly for 20 years; strengthened Board of Control

context.background: Company's charter needed renewal; Parliament assessed Company's performance
context.duration: Extended Company's charter for another 20 years

mainProvisions: Charter Extension: Company's commercial monopoly extended for 20 years
Board of Control: Powers substantially increased over Company
Governor-General: Powers further strengthened
Civil Servants: Regulations for selection and payment
Financial Control: Company required to pay ¬£500,000 annually to British government
Legislative Authority: Governor-General's government could make regulations
Presidencies: Control system refined
Accountability: Increased reporting to Parliament
details.significance: Enhanced Board of Control's authority; made Company more accountable to Parliament; laid foundation for separation of executive and judicial functions
details.note: This Act did not introduce major constitutional changes but consolidated previous reforms

events.title: The Charter Act of 1813
events.description: End of Company's trade monopoly; Christian missionaries allowed

context.background: British industrialists demanded free trade with India; missionaries wanted access; Indian trade too profitable to remain monopoly
context.resistance: Company resisted but Parliament imposed changes

mainProvisions: Trade Monopoly Ended: Company's trade monopoly with India abolished (except China tea trade)
Free Trade: British subjects allowed to trade with India with license
Christian Missionaries: Permitted to preach in India
Indian Education: ¬£1 lakh annually for education of Indians in British territories
Charter Extension: Extended for another 20 years
Company's Position: Retained territorial control
Local Governments: Powers of provincial governments defined
Financial Separation: Commercial and territorial revenues to be kept separate
details.significance: Watershed moment - Company became administrative body rather than trading company; beginning of free trade era; opening to missionary activities
details.impact: Led to influx of British merchants, rise of modern education, spread of Christianity, and British cultural influence

events.title: The Charter Act of 1833
events.description: Complete end of Company's commercial activities; administrative centralization

context.background: Industrial Revolution in Britain; demand for completely free trade; Company's commercial role questioned
context.significance: Most comprehensive administrative reform till date

mainProvisions: Commercial Activities Ended: Company ceased to be commercial entity entirely
China Trade: Even China tea trade monopoly abolished
Administrative Body: Company became purely administrative agent of British Crown
Governor-General of India: Title changed from 'Governor-General of Bengal' to 'Governor-General of India'
Centralized Legislature: Governor-General's government became legislative authority for entire India
Law Member: 4th member (Law Member) added to Governor-General's Council
Equality in Employment: Indians not to be debarred from any office on grounds of religion, color, birth, descent
Civil Services: Open competition recommended (not implemented)
Slavery: Attempted to abolish slavery
Charter: Extended for 20 years
details.significance: Company transformed into administrative agent of Crown; centralization of legislation; first official recognition of Indians' right to hold office (though rarely implemented)
notablePoints: Lord William Bentinck was Governor-General when Act passed
Beginning of centralized law-making for all of India

events.title: The Charter Act of 1853
events.description: Last Charter Act; introduction of competitive exams for civil services; legislative reforms

context.background: Growing criticism of Company rule; need for professional administration; demand for legislative reforms

mainProvisions: No Time Limit: Charter extended without time limit (till Parliament decided otherwise)
Competitive Exams: Open competitive examination for Indian Civil Services introduced
Law Member: Made full member of Governor-General's Council (earlier only for legislative work)
Legislative Council: Separate legislative council created (6 additional members)
Provincial Representation: Provincial governments to be represented in legislative council
Legislative Process: Procedure similar to British Parliament
Governor-General's Authority: Executive and legislative functions separated
Local Governments: Lieutenant Governors for Bengal, Bombay, Madras
Patronage Ended: Directors' patronage in appointments abolished
details.significance: Introduced competitive merit-based civil service; separated legislative and executive functions; laid foundation for parliamentary system in India

historicalContext.aftermath: After revolt, Company rule ended completely (Government of India Act 1858)

examImportant: Only Charter Act without time limit
First to introduce competitive exams (Macaulay Committee recommendation implemented)

summary.title: Evolution Pattern
progression: 1784: Dual government established ‚Üí Board of Control + Company
1853: Modern administration ‚Üí Competitive exams, Legislative reforms
1858: Company rule ends ‚Üí Crown takes over (after 1857 Revolt)
summary.examStrategy: Remember in chronological order; focus on what was NEW in each Act; understand the progression from commercial company to administrative agent to Crown rule
